title: Operational Practices
description: Requirements for operational practices including dropped product protocols, product protection procedures, contamination prevention during operations, and proper handling of damaged or defective products

requirements.text: Does the process flow, facility layout, worker control, utensil control, internal vehicle use, etc. ensure that finished products are not contaminated by raw products/ingredients?
mandatoryStatements: Process flow must prevent cross-contamination between raw and finished products
Physical separation or time separation must be implemented
Worker and equipment movement must be controlled
Utensils must be segregated for raw vs. finished products
Traffic patterns must support contamination prevention
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly facility flow assessment for cross-contamination risks, annual review of traffic patterns and controls
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily supervision of worker and equipment flow, weekly verification of process flow controls

requirements.text: Are all exposed materials (product, packaging, etc.) protected from overhead contamination (e.g., ladders, drive assemblies, condensation, lubricants, walkways, loose panels, degrading insulation, etc.)?
mandatoryStatements: Exposed products and packaging must be protected from overhead contamination sources
Drip shields or guards must be installed where needed
Overhead infrastructure must be maintained to prevent degradation
Condensation must be controlled and directed away from products
Regular overhead inspections must be conducted
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly overhead infrastructure inspection, quarterly assessment of product protection measures
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily visual verification of product protection, immediate response to overhead hazards

requirements.text: Are production areas clean and well maintained; especially lights, ducts, fans, floor areas by the walls and equipment, and other hard to reach areas?
mandatoryStatements: Production areas must be maintained in clean condition
Cleaning schedules must include hard-to-reach areas
Overhead structures, lights, and ducts must be included in cleaning
Floor-wall junctions and areas around equipment must be cleaned regularly
Master sanitation schedule must address all areas
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly inspection of production area cleanliness including hard-to-reach areas, monthly deep cleaning verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily pre-operational inspections, immediate cleaning if deficiencies identified

requirements.text: Where facilities are not completely enclosed, are there measures in place to mitigate potential hazards?
mandatoryStatements: Open or semi-enclosed facilities must implement specific hazard mitigation measures
Protection from weather, pests, and dust must be provided
Environmental risk assessment must be documented
Additional controls appropriate to exposure level must be implemented
Regular monitoring must verify control effectiveness
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly assessment of environmental hazard controls in open facilities, annual risk assessment review
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily monitoring of environmental conditions and control measures, immediate response to adverse conditions

requirements.text: Is all re-work / re-packaging handled correctly?
mandatoryStatements: Rework procedures must be documented and followed
Rework materials must be properly identified and segregated
Food safety assessment must be conducted before re-integration
Traceability must be maintained through rework process
Approval procedures must be established for rework use
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly audit of rework handling procedures and records, quarterly food safety assessment review
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily supervision of rework handling, documentation verification for each rework batch

requirements.text: Are raw ingredients examined before use?
mandatoryStatements: Raw ingredients must be inspected before use
Inspection criteria must be documented
Defective materials must be rejected and segregated
Inspection records must be maintained
Supplier notification procedures must exist for quality issues
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly audit of receiving inspection records and procedures, annual supplier quality review
requirements.monitoringExpectations: 100% visual inspection of raw ingredients before use, immediate rejection of defective materials

requirements.text: Are products produced on-site coded (carton and unit packaging) for the day of production?
mandatoryStatements: All products must be coded with production date on carton and unit packaging
Coding equipment must be maintained and calibrated
Code verification procedures must be implemented
Coding must enable traceability and recall capability
Missing or illegible codes must halt production until corrected
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily verification of code legibility and accuracy, monthly coding equipment maintenance
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous verification of coding during production, immediate correction of coding failures

requirements.text: Are foreign material control methods (e.g., metal detectors, metal traps, magnets, x-ray machines, visual inspection, etc.) in place and regularly tested (where relevant) to ensure proper operation?
mandatoryStatements: Foreign material control devices must be installed at appropriate points
Regular sensitivity testing must be conducted and documented
Test pieces must be maintained for verification
Device failures must halt production until corrected
Affected product must be evaluated if device fails testing
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly verification of test documentation completeness, quarterly calibration of detection equipment
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily or per-shift sensitivity testing of foreign material detection devices, immediate response to failures

requirements.text: Does the facility use the appropriate method and equipment for verifying the concentrations of the anti-microbial chemical (product contact water, terminal sanitizers, dip stations, etc.) being used?
mandatoryStatements: Appropriate test methods and equipment must be used for chemical concentration verification
Test equipment must be calibrated and maintained
Concentration testing frequency must be established and followed
Out-of-specification results must trigger immediate corrective action
Testing records must be maintained and reviewed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly calibration of test equipment, monthly review of concentration testing records
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Hourly or per-batch concentration testing during operations, immediate adjustment for out-of-spec results

requirements.text: Are hand washing stations adequate in number and appropriately located for worker access and monitoring usage?
mandatoryStatements: Handwashing stations must be adequate in number based on workforce
Stations must be strategically located for easy worker access
Stations must be positioned to enable supervisory monitoring
Stations must be at facility entry points and after restroom use
Additional stations must be added as workforce increases
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly assessment of handwashing station adequacy and locations, annual facility layout review
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily verification that all stations are accessible and functional, continuous observation of handwashing compliance

requirements.text: Are hand washing stations in working order, have water of suitable temperature and pressure, adequately stocked (e.g. disposable towels, unscented soap, etc.) and restricted to hand washing purposes only?
mandatoryStatements: Handwashing stations must be fully functional with tempered running water
Water temperature must be suitable for handwashing (warm, not scalding)
Stations must be stocked with liquid soap and single-use towels
Waste receptacles must be provided and emptied regularly
Stations must be dedicated to handwashing only, not other uses
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily functionality and stocking verification, monthly water temperature measurements
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Multiple daily checks of station functionality and supplies, immediate repair and restocking as needed

requirements.text: Are toilet facilities adequate in number and location and are they appropriately stocked (e.g., toilet paper.)?
mandatoryStatements: Toilet facilities must be adequate in number per regulatory requirements
Facilities must be conveniently located to minimize worker travel time
Facilities must be properly stocked with toilet paper and waste receptacles
Facilities must be maintained in sanitary condition
Regular cleaning schedules must be established and followed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily cleanliness inspection and supply verification, quarterly adequacy assessment based on workforce
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Multiple daily checks of facility cleanliness and supplies, immediate cleaning and restocking as needed

requirements.text: Are secondary hand sanitation stations adequate in number and location, and are the stations maintained properly?
mandatoryStatements: Secondary hand sanitizing stations must supplement handwashing stations
Stations must be adequate in number and strategically located
Alcohol-based or approved sanitizers must be provided
Stations must be maintained with supplies and functionality
Stations supplement but do not replace handwashing requirements
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly verification of station functionality and supply levels, monthly adequacy assessment
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily checks of sanitizer levels and dispenser function, immediate refilling as needed

requirements.text: Are foot baths, foamers or dry powdered sanitizing stations adequate in number and location, and are the stations maintained properly?
mandatoryStatements: Foot sanitation stations must be located at facility entry points and between zones
Chemical concentration or mat effectiveness must be maintained
Regular cleaning and solution replacement must be performed
Stations must be adequately sized to prevent bypassing
Monitoring procedures must verify proper maintenance
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly chemical concentration testing or mat condition assessment, monthly station effectiveness review
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily verification of chemical concentration or mat condition, solution changes per established schedule

requirements.text: Are single service containers used for their intended purpose only so that potential cross contamination is prevented?
mandatoryStatements: Single-service containers must be used only for their intended purpose
Containers must be discarded after single use
Reuse of single-service containers is prohibited
Clear visual differentiation from reusable containers must exist
Adequate supplies must be provided to prevent reuse temptation
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly audit of container use practices, quarterly training verification on proper container handling
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily supervision of container use, immediate correction of any reuse attempts

requirements.text: Are re-usable containers cleanable and clearly designated for the specific purpose (trash, raw product, finished product, re-work, ice, etc.) such that cross contamination is prevented?
mandatoryStatements: Reusable containers must be constructed of cleanable materials
Containers must be clearly designated and color-coded for specific purposes
Designation must prevent use for incompatible materials
Cleaning and sanitizing procedures must be established
Container use must be monitored and audited regularly
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly audit of container designation and proper use, quarterly inspection of container condition and cleanability
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily verification of proper container use and designation, immediate correction of misuse

requirements.text: Are devices used to measure, regulate or control temperature, pH, acidity, water activity, and other conditions that affect food safety, working properly and adequately maintained?
mandatoryStatements: Monitoring and control devices must be properly calibrated and maintained
Calibration schedules must be established and followed
Device malfunctions must be addressed immediately
Backup measurement methods must be available
Calibration records must be maintained with traceability to standards
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly calibration verification against certified standards, annual review of all monitoring devices
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily functionality checks of critical monitoring devices, immediate repair or replacement of malfunctioning equipment

mandatoryStatements: Process flow and facility layout must prevent cross-contamination between raw and finished products through physical separation, directional flow, personnel controls, and equipment/utensil segregation

All exposed food products, ingredients, and packaging materials must be protected from overhead contamination sources including condensation, lubricants, broken lights, degrading infrastructure, and personnel traffic on elevated platforms

Production areas must be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition with particular attention to overhead structures, lighting fixtures, ventilation ducts, floor-wall junctions, and areas around equipment that are difficult to access

Open or semi-enclosed facilities must implement specific hazard mitigation measures appropriate to the environmental risks including protection from weather, pests, dust, and other external contamination sources

Rework and re-packaging operations must be controlled through documented procedures that ensure proper identification, segregation, handling, and re-integration into production without compromising food safety or quality
Raw ingredients must be visually inspected before use to detect defects, contamination, or quality issues that could affect finished product safety or quality
All products produced on-site must be coded on both carton and unit packaging with production date information to enable traceability and recall capability

Foreign material control devices (metal detectors, x-ray machines, filters, screens, magnets) must be installed at critical control points, regularly tested for sensitivity and effectiveness, and maintained in proper working order

Antimicrobial chemical concentrations (sanitizers, chlorine, peroxyacetic acid, etc.) used on product contact surfaces or in product contact water must be verified using appropriate test methods and equipment with documented frequency and results

Handwashing stations must be adequate in number based on workforce size, strategically located for easy worker access at facility entry points and after restroom use, and positioned to enable supervisor monitoring of compliance

Handwashing stations must be fully functional with tempered running water, liquid soap (unscented preferred), single-use towels, waste receptacles, and signage; stations must be dedicated to handwashing only, not used for other purposes

Toilet facilities must be adequate in number per regulatory requirements, conveniently located to minimize worker travel time, properly stocked with toilet paper and waste receptacles, and maintained in sanitary condition

Secondary hand sanitizing stations (alcohol-based or other approved sanitizers) must supplement handwashing stations, be adequate in number and location throughout production areas, and maintained with supplies and functionality

Foot baths, foam sanitizing stations, or dry sanitizer mat stations must be strategically located at facility entry points and between zones, maintained at proper chemical concentrations or effectiveness, and cleaned/replaced regularly

Single-service containers and utensils must be used only for their intended purpose and discarded after use to prevent cross-contamination; they must never be reused for different materials or applications

Reusable containers must be constructed of cleanable materials, clearly designated and color-coded for specific purposes (raw vs. cooked, allergen vs. non-allergen, product vs. waste), and maintained in sanitary condition

Monitoring and control devices (thermometers, pH meters, water activity meters, etc.) must be properly calibrated, maintained in working order, and verified for accuracy according to defined schedules to ensure critical parameters remain within food safety limits
capaInject: If cross-contamination risks are identified in process flow, immediately implement physical barriers or spatial separation, establish directional traffic patterns with clearly marked flow paths, designate separate equipment and utensils for raw and finished products, and consider time-separation if space is limited

When overhead contamination hazards are discovered, immediately protect exposed products by covering or moving them, repair or replace damaged infrastructure (lights, panels, insulation), install drip shields or splash guards under equipment, and implement routine overhead inspection and maintenance programs

For production area cleanliness deficiencies, immediately conduct deep cleaning including all hard-to-reach areas, establish a master sanitation schedule with defined frequencies and responsibilities, implement pre-operational inspections with documented verification, and increase cleaning frequency in problem areas

In open or semi-enclosed facilities with inadequate hazard mitigation, immediately assess environmental risks, install barriers such as air curtains, screens, or plastic strip curtains, establish enhanced cleaning protocols, implement environmental monitoring programs, and consider infrastructure improvements for permanent enclosure

When rework or re-packaging procedures are not followed correctly, immediately segregate and hold affected materials, conduct food safety assessment, establish written rework procedures with approval steps and traceability requirements, train personnel on proper handling, and implement supervisory verification

If raw ingredient inspection reveals quality or safety defects, immediately reject and segregate defective materials, notify supplier of issues, enhance receiving inspection procedures with documented standards and training for inspectors, and consider supplier corrective action requests or alternate sourcing

When production coding is missing, incorrect, or illegible, immediately halt production until coding equipment is repaired, verify affected product lot identification through production records, implement coding verification checks, establish preventive maintenance for coding equipment, and train operators on proper code application

If foreign material control devices fail sensitivity tests, immediately stop production, recalibrate or repair equipment, establish test procedures with documented frequency and sensitivity standards, maintain test pieces and records, and evaluate affected products produced since last successful test for potential contamination

When antimicrobial chemical concentrations are out of specification, immediately discontinue use, prepare fresh solution at proper concentration, establish written procedures for mixing and testing, verify test equipment calibration, train personnel on proper testing methods, and increase monitoring frequency during start-up periods

For inadequate handwashing station capacity or accessibility, immediately increase the number of stations based on workforce and facility layout assessment, relocate stations to high-traffic areas and facility entry points, ensure visibility for monitoring purposes, and post multilingual handwashing instruction signs

When handwashing stations are non-functional or inadequately stocked, immediately repair or replace equipment, establish daily stocking and functionality checks with documented accountability, install appropriate signage restricting use to handwashing only, and implement disciplinary measures for misuse

If toilet facilities are inadequate or unsanitary, immediately clean and sanitize facilities, increase number of toilets based on workforce size and regulatory requirements, establish frequent cleaning and restocking schedules with documented completion, and install self-closing doors and proper ventilation

When secondary hand sanitizing stations are inadequate, immediately install additional stations at strategic locations (production entry points, after glove changes, between tasks), verify sanitizer effectiveness and concentration, establish refill and maintenance schedules, and train workers on proper use supplementing handwashing

For inadequate or poorly maintained foot sanitation stations, immediately replace sanitizing solutions or mats, verify proper chemical concentration using test strips, establish daily monitoring and replacement schedules, ensure adequate sizing to prevent bypassing, and implement supervisory verification of worker compliance

If single-service containers are being reused, immediately remove all single-service items from production area, provide adequate supplies of appropriate containers for all uses, educate personnel on cross-contamination risks, establish clear visual differentiation between single-service and reusable items, and implement spot-checks for compliance

When reusable containers lack proper designation or are used for wrong purposes, immediately implement color-coding system with clear labeling, segregate containers by use category, establish cleaning and sanitizing procedures specific to each container type, train personnel on proper container selection, and audit container use regularly

If monitoring/control devices are malfunctioning or out of calibration, immediately remove from service, calibrate or replace devices using certified standards, establish preventive maintenance and calibration schedules, maintain calibration records with traceability to certified standards, and verify critical control parameters using backup measurement methods until primary devices are restored
traceabilityInject: Maintain facility layout diagrams clearly showing raw product zones, finished product zones, physical barriers, traffic flow patterns, and critical control points for cross-contamination prevention

Document overhead protection measures including locations of drip shields, equipment maintenance schedules for overhead infrastructure, and inspection records identifying and correcting potential overhead contamination sources

Keep master sanitation schedules and cleaning logs for production areas documenting date, areas cleaned, cleaning agents used, personnel responsible, and verification inspections with corrective actions for deficiencies

Retain rework handling records including identification of rework materials, food safety assessment, reprocessing procedures followed, lot traceability through rework process, and approval for re-integration into production

Maintain receiving inspection records for raw ingredients showing date received, lot identification, condition assessment, defects noted, acceptance/rejection decision, and supplier notification of quality issues

Keep production coding records documenting code formats used, coding equipment maintenance and calibration, verification checks of code legibility and accuracy, and troubleshooting records for coding failures

Document foreign material control device testing records including test date, device location, test method, sensitivity verification, pass/fail results, corrective actions for failures, and preventive maintenance activities

Retain antimicrobial chemical monitoring logs showing sanitizer type, concentration testing results, test method used, frequency of testing, corrective actions for out-of-specification results, and equipment calibration records

Maintain handwashing station monitoring records documenting daily functionality checks, stocking verification, maintenance activities, worker compliance observations, and corrective actions for deficiencies

Keep toilet facility cleaning and maintenance logs showing cleaning frequency, restocking activities, functionality issues, repairs completed, and compliance with regulatory requirements for number of facilities

Document foot bath and secondary sanitizing station maintenance records including solution preparation dates, concentration testing results, replacement frequency, effectiveness verification, and corrective actions

Retain container management records showing container designation, color-coding schemes, cleaning and sanitizing logs, inspection findings, and corrective actions for misuse or cross-contamination risks

Maintain calibration and maintenance records for all monitoring devices (thermometers, pH meters, water activity meters) including calibration standards used, calibration frequency, results, adjustments made, and device replacement history
micro_inject: Cross-contamination between raw and ready-to-eat products can transfer pathogenic bacteria including Listeria monocytogenes, Salmonella, and E. coli O157:H7, causing serious foodborne illness outbreaks with high morbidity and mortality rates

Overhead contamination from condensation provides moisture that supports growth of psychrotrophic pathogens like Listeria that can multiply at refrigeration temperatures, while lubricant drips can contain heavy metals and toxic compounds

Inadequate cleaning of production areas allows biofilm formation on surfaces and equipment where Listeria monocytogenes and other pathogens can persist for months or years, continuously contaminating products despite cleaning efforts

Open facility environments expose products to airborne pathogens, dust containing Salmonella or E. coli from animal sources, and opportunistic pathogens from environmental sources including water and soil

Improper rework handling can re-introduce aged materials with elevated pathogen levels back into fresh production, or mix products with different food safety profiles creating unpredictable contamination patterns

Defective raw ingredients may harbor high levels of pathogenic bacteria, mycotoxins, or allergens that processing steps cannot adequately eliminate, leading to contamination of finished products throughout the production run

Foreign material contamination can introduce pathogenic bacteria from environmental sources; for example, metal fragments may carry soil bacteria including Clostridium botulinum spores or Listeria from outdoor environments

Inadequate antimicrobial chemical concentrations fail to achieve log reductions in pathogen levels on product contact surfaces or in wash water, allowing bacterial survival and product contamination, while excessive concentrations can leave toxic residues

Poor hand hygiene is one of the primary vectors for transmitting fecal pathogens (E. coli, Salmonella, Shigella, Hepatitis A, Norovirus) from workers to food products, causing numerous large-scale outbreaks annually

Inadequate toilet facilities or handwashing access increases the likelihood of fecal contamination entering the production environment through worker contact with products, equipment, or food contact surfaces

Secondary sanitizing stations supplement handwashing but do not replace it; alcohol-based sanitizers are less effective against non-enveloped viruses (Norovirus, Hepatitis A) and bacterial spores requiring proper handwashing as the primary control

Foot traffic between contaminated and clean areas can transfer pathogens on shoe soles; foot baths with inadequate sanitizer concentration or infrequent changes become sources of contamination rather than control points

Container misuse creates cross-contamination pathways transferring allergens, pathogens, or chemical residues between incompatible materials; for example, containers used for raw product and then finished product without adequate cleaning

Malfunctioning temperature control allows rapid pathogen multiplication; Salmonella can double every 20 minutes at room temperature, while inadequate pH control can permit growth of acid-tolerant pathogens like E. coli O157:H7 in acidified products
